column1: Port Orchard is a city in and the county seat of Kitsap County
column3: United States. It is located 13 miles (21 km) due west of West Seattle and is connected to Seattle and Vashon Island via the Washington State Ferries run to Southworth. It is named after Port Orchard
column4: the strait that separates Bainbridge Island from the Kitsap Peninsula.

column1: As of the 2010 census the population was 11
column3: and in 2019 the population was an estimated 14

column1: The first European-Americans to settle in what is now Port Orchard were William Renton and Daniel Howard
column2: who set up a sawmill there in 1854. The town that was to become Port Orchard was originally platted in 1886 by Frederick Stevens
column3: who named the new location after his father
column4: Sidney. The town of Sidney was incorporated September 15
column6: and was the first in Kitsap County to be both platted and incorporated. Shortly thereafter
column7: the U.S. Navy sought a suitable location for another installation on the West Coast
column8: and found it with the assistance of Sidney's residents in Orchard Bay (this installation would later become the Puget Sound Naval Shipyard in Bremerton).

column1: The county seat was originally in Port Madison
column2: but moved to Sidney after a popular vote in 1892. In December of that same year
column3: the residents of Sidney petitioned both the state legislature and the Post Office Department to rename the city "Port Orchard". The legislature refused
column4: as Charleston (now West Bremerton) had also requested that name. The Post Office Department
column6: went through with the name change
column7: and as a result the Port Orchard post office ended up in Sidney
column8: and the Charleston post office ended up in Port Orchard. It wasn't until 1903 that local politician Will Thompson convinced the state legislature to correct this confusing situation
column9: and relocated the Charleston post office to Charleston
column10: at the same time renaming Sidney "Port Orchard"

column3: a cul-de-sac in Port Orchard was struck by an EF-2 tornado with winds between 120 and 130 miles per hour (190 and 210 km/h)
column4: the strongest tornado in Washington since 1986. The tornado uprooted trees and damaged up to 450 homes and businesses
column5: some of which sustained total roof loss. Some neighborhoods were evacuated due to reported gas leaks.

column1: Port Orchard is located in south-central Kitsap County at 47°31′54″N 122°38′18″W (47.531563
column3: on the south side of Sinclair Inlet
column4: an arm of the Port Orchard strait connecting to Puget Sound. The city is bordered to the north across Sinclair Inlet by the city of Bremerton.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: Port Orchard has a total area of 8.5 square miles (22.1 km2)
column3: of which 7.3 square miles (18.8 km2) are land and 1.3 square miles (3.3 km2)
column6: located 7 miles (11 km) south of the city
column7: is a private airport with an industrial park.

column1: The median age in the city was 34.5 years. 23.5% of residents were under the age of 18; 10.4% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 29.1% were from 25 to 44; 23.4% were from 45 to 64; and 13.5% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 50.3% male and 49.7% female.
